journal-meta.journal-title: The Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design

title-group.article-title: New approaches to optimize strain behavior of Al6082 during equal channel angular pressing

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Maragheh, Maragheh, Iran
3Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA
4Department of Mechanical Engineering, College of Engineering, Qassim University, Saudi Arabia

author-notes.corresp: Mahmood Ebrahimi, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran 16846-13114, Iran. Email: mebrahimi@iust.ac.ir

abstract.p: Equal channel angular pressing is one of the attractive methods of severe plastic deformation techniques to fabricate ultrafine grained materials. In this study, eight different equal channel angular pressing configurations including the punch shape, sample preform and die geometry have been analyzed using finite element method to achieve materials with the high effective strain magnitude, better strain distribution uniformity and less required pressing force. The results show that the combination of punch shape and back slant specimen is the most efficient modification as compared to the conventional equal channel angular pressing process. Furthermore, investigations on various die channel and sample slant angles indicate that the configuration of punch shape and back slant sample with the die channel angle of 75° and sample slant angle of 30° is the optimum condition. Finally, experimental work has been performed to validate the results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As a principle, average grain size of material is one of the significant parameters influencing physical and mechanical behaviors in the case of engineering metals and alloys.1,2 One of the methods to fabricate ultrafine grained (UFG) materials is severe plastic deformation (SPD).3 The main advantage of SPD processes is that the initial dimension of the specimen does not change after process; hence, by repeating the operation several times, the desired grain size is achieved. Equal channel angular pressing (ECAP) is one of the attractive methods of SPD techniques to fabricate UFG materials. A general view of ECAP die and its basic parameters are shown in Figure 1. In ECAP process, a cylindrical-shaped specimen is pressed through a die constrained within a channel that is bent through an abrupt angle, Φ, and with a corner curvature angle, Ψ.4–6 To date, various properties of equal channel angular pressed (ECAPed) materials including mechanical, fatigue, magnetic, thermal, superplastic, corrosion, creep and wear have been investigated,7–9 and several engineering applications of this technology have been experimented and reported. Consolidation of commercially pure titanium chips into fully bulk material with high strength and good ductility using ECAP process with back pressure,10 production of gears for microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) applications, Ti implants in surgical procedures and wire-typed specimen in large scale using continuous processing techniques of ECAP process such as ECAP-Conform setup and integrated ECAP-Extrusion process11 and manufacturing of high-strength aluminum bolts using ECAP with split die setup12 and with spring-loaded auto fastening setup in mass production13 are some examples of the engineering application of this SPD method.

caption.p: Schematic representation of conventional ECAP setup and general parameters.

sec.p: The amount of shear strain (γ) imposed to the billet through 1-pass ECAP process in the frictionless condition is estimated by Iwahashi et al. Also, the equivalent plastic strain (εN) that is imparted to the billet after N pass can be expressed as14

The imposed strain along the longitudinal direction of the ECAPed sample in the conventional ECAP process is not uniform. There are three parts based on the strain distribution homogeneity within the pressed workpiece. These are front (head) and end (tail) with nonuniform strain distribution and steady-state zones represented in Figure 2. Also, die channel angle (Φ) and outer corner angle (Ψ) have an effect on the magnitude and distribution of strain.15–18

caption.p: Front and end zone positions in the deformed sample.

sec.p: On the contrary, various optimizations and modifications on the ECAP process have been proposed and investigated for achieving a better strain distribution.19–22 Numerical investigation of optimal processing route by Suo et al.23 implied that the best deformation homogeneity of ECAPed sample is achieved using route BC. Djavanroodi et al.24 showed that the use of covered tube casing (CTC) technique can result in better deformation homogeneity of ECAP materials. New ECAP pressing route, called route BC-UD2, was proposed by Liang et al.25 in which both grain refinement and particle redistribution is obtained. Plastic deformation behavior of cross-shaped equal channel angular pressing (C-ECAP) instead of a conventional L-shaped channel was investigated by Nagasekhar and Kim.26 It was shown that it is impossible to obtain strain uniformity in this method. Yoon et al.27 expressed that sample preform design is an effective means in order to obtain materials with homogeneous deformation and less punch load as compared to the conventional state. For the back slant preform condition, the required load overshoot is eliminated, and the surface folding defects do not occur; thus, this shape is determined to be the most effective among the assessed preform shapes.
Effective strain (ES) distribution has been studied using inhomogeneity factor (IF) or coefficient of standard deviation18

where εave is the average strain, εi is the ES in each element and n is the number of data. Lower value for IF means that better strain distribution uniformity for ECAPed sample. This factor is calculated and compared for the various ECAP modeled types in this research.

As mentioned above, the front and end zones of the billet (about 20% of the billet volume) are considered not suitable for further use, and it is a major source of material waste. Also, one of the major challenges in this process is obtaining a homogeneous material, and since strain is a major contributor, studying the strain behavior is very important. The authors in their previous studies have investigated the effect of material properties (K and n), processes parameters (die channel angle, friction coefficient, back punch pressure, die channel angle and channel displacement in the ECAP with parallel channel) and processes modification (CTC) on the strain behavior of ECAPed materials.19,24,28 In this article, the influences of specimen, punch and die shapes have been investigated on the strain characteristics. For this study, commercial 6082 aluminum (Al6082) billets were ECAPed 1 pass, and the obtained data were used for validating simulations. Eight ECAP conditions including of punch shape, sample preform and die geometry have been simulated to optimize strain behavior of deformed specimens. Furthermore, various billet slant angles and die channel angles have been analyzed and discussed. The aim of this research is to produce materials with least wastage, higher ES magnitude and better strain dispersal homogeneity. Finally, the magnitudes of required pressing force to perform the process are evaluated.

sec.title: Experimental procedure
sec.p: Billets of commercial Al6082 with the dimension of 11 × 11 × 85 mm3 were employed as the test samples. The chemical composition of material is listed in Table 1. The specimens were solution treated at 540 °C for 1.5 h and then cooled slowly to room temperature at the furnace before operation. It leads to homogeneous and uniform structure with good ductility. ECAP die with the die channel angle of 90° and outer corner angle of 18° was designed and manufactured. Die with channel angle of 90° results in high angle grain boundaries (HAGBs) and strong deformation textures and also a low shear deformation layer close to the outer corner walls.1,4 It has also been shown that die channel angle lower and higher than 90° would result in higher and lower ESs at the bottom surface of the sample, respectively.28 The die was made of SKD61 tool steel. Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) was used as a lubricant to diminish the frictional influence between the die and the sample. Also, the value of punch speed was equal to 1 mm s−1.

caption.p: Chemical composition of Al6082 used in this research.

sec.title: Finite element modeling
sec.p: The simulation of ECAP process was carried out using commercial DEFORM-3D™ software. In this model, the plastic deformation behavior of the material has been defined as

where σ is the effective von Mises stress, ε is the effective plastic strain, K is the strength coefficient and n is the strain hardening exponent. To obtain K and n values, tensile test was performed on Al sample according to ASTM B557M (2010). The tensile test was repeated three times, and the average magnitudes of strength coefficient and strain hardening exponent were used. The die and punch were assumed to be rigid, so that there is no deformation. The constant punch speed was assumed to be 1 mm s−1 as same as the experimental procedure. The effect of temperature on the operation can be neglected if ECAP process is performed at the ambient temperature with the low punch rate.29,30 In order to determine the optimum mesh size, mesh sensitivity diagram was plotted to investigate the convergence of results and to choose proper mesh element size. The optimum mesh element numbers were chosen as 41,000. The mesh type was tetrahedral and finer internal mesh was utilized. Also, during large plastic deformation, if an object satisfies any of its remeshing criteria, a new mesh is generated, and the solution data are interpolated to the new mesh from the old one. For this case, automatic remeshing was applied to accommodate large deformation during the simulations using global remeshing with interference of 0.4 mm (absolute). Furthermore, the magnitudes of ES were obtained by averaging the value of strain (41,000 elements) in each simulation. Figure 3 shows finite element mesh and true stress–strain curve of Al6082 billet for modeling of ECAP process.

caption.p: (a) Finite element mesh system and (b) true stress–strain of Al6082 sample for modeling of ECAP process.

sec.p: The ECAP process parameters including side of square cross-sectional sample (a), length of sample (L), shear friction coefficient between the die and specimen (m), strength coefficient of material (K) and strain hardening exponent of material (n) are listed in Table 2. These magnitudes have been selected based on the values applied in the experimental part.

caption.p: ECAP process parameters used in this research.

sec.p: The pressing force is an important factor in metal forming, and so, other significant parameters can affect this factor during the process. Hence, as a validation of the simulated results, required pressing force can be compared with the experimental work. If the punch force in the simulation agrees well with that in the experiment at the same punch position with all similar conditions, the outputs in the finite element method (FEM) are considered as agreeable values. In the current study, process modeling is verified with both theoretical and experimental procedures.

sec.title: Upper-bound theory
sec.p: Upper-bound theory verification is also performed based on the solution of previous studies. Equation (5) represents the maximum limit of required force to press sample in the ECAP process31

where F is the required punch force, a is the side of square cross-sectional sample, τo is the shear yield stress, m is the friction coefficient, (li+ lo) = (L − a) and L is the total length of the sample, respectively. Table 1 lists the magnitudes of Φ, Ψ, K, n, a, m and L that have been used in equation (5). The die, sample and process parameters were considered identical to those of the experimental work. The magnitude of punch force based on the upper-bound solution is 89 kN. Since the upper-bound theory anticipates upper limit of required pressing force, it is expected that the result of upper-bound method is more than the actual value.

sec.title: Verification of FEM
sec.p: As already mentioned, all die, sample and process parameters in the upper-bound solution and numerical analysis were considered identical to the experimental work. To verify FEM results, simulated load–stroke curve, peak load and theoretical calculations were compared with the experimentally recorded load–stroke curve and peak load. Figure 4 displays curves of required punch force to press Al specimen through the conventional ECAP die, which are obtained with experimental, analytical and numerical methods. After 1 pass, the maximum required pressing force magnitudes obtained by the experimental work, theoretical and the simulation results are 84, 89 and 80 kN, respectively. There are about 7% and 3.5% differences for the theoretical and numerical analyses with the experimental work, respectively, which are acceptable for all practical purposes. It can be concluded that satisfactory agreement is achieved between the magnitudes of required pressing force.

caption.p: Comparison of experimental required ECAP punch force with upper-bound method (UBM) and finite element modeling (FEM).

sec.p: The schematic representation of eight different ECAP process parameters consisting of punch shape, sample preform and die geometry configurations are displayed in Figure 5. These configurations are conventional setup referred as C (Figure 5(a)), punch shape referred as P (Figure 5(b)), front slant sample referred as FS (Figure 5(c)), back slant sample referred as BS (Figure 5(d)), combination of punch shape and front slant sample referred as P-FS (Figure 5(e)), combination of punch shape and back slant sample referred as P-BS (Figure 5(f)), combination of die geometry and front slant sample referred as D-FS (Figure 5(g)) and combination of die geometry, front slant sample and punch shape referred as D-FS-P (Figure 5(h)).

caption.p: Various ECAP process configurations analyzed with the FEM: (a) C, (b) P, (c) FS, (d) BS, (e) P-FS, (f) P-BS, (g) D-FS and (h) D-FS-P.

sec.title: Effect of punch shape, sample preform and die geometry
sec.p: The optimized situation of the all eight conditions are the configuration that has the higher magnitude of average ES, better strain distribution uniformity (lower value for IF) and lower required pressing force. By considering these circumstances, a material with both strong mechanical properties and isotropic characteristic can be fabricated with good industrial application. Figure 6 represents the magnitudes of ES, IF and required extrusion force (RF) for the described ECAP process configurations.

caption.p: Magnitudes of effective strain (ES), inhomogeneity factor (IF) and required pressing force (RF) for the eight various ECAP process conditions.

sec.p: It is observed that modification of only punch shape results in increasing the ES value up to 5.8% and decreasing the IF magnitude down to 11.3% as compared to the conventional ECAP condition. Also, it causes more than 6% reduction on the RF. Therefore, punch shape modification does have considerable effects on ECAP process.

It is also observed that using only slant specimens can cause an improving tendency on the IF value (down to 3% and 12.7% for the front and back slants, respectively) as compared to the conventional ECAP. Furthermore, the front and back slants reduces the forming force values by 2.5% and 7.5%, respectively; however, a reduction on the value of ES (3.7% and 10.5%) is inevitable.

Applying modification on the punch shape and specimen slant simultaneously develops the most effective conditions. For the cases of P-FS and P-BS, it is concluded that an approximate 9% and 0% enhancements, respectively, are obtained on the ES values as compared to the C situation. These circumstances are coupled with 11.3% and 18.7% improvement on the IF magnitudes, that is, better strain distribution homogeneity can be achieved by using the P-FS and P-BS situations. It is interesting to note that these desired outputs are accompanied with about 6.2% and 10% reductions on the RF for the P-FS and P-BS conditions, respectively, as compared with the C condition. From the strain dispersal uniformity point of view through the ECAP process in the deformed billet, P-BS gives the best performance among all eight above-mentioned configurations. Based on the IF values (strain distribution homogeneity on the ECAPed specimen), P-BS is anticipated to be the most optimized condition.

For die geometry modification cases, the most prominent problem is the difficulty and complication of manufacturing new die. The combination of die geometry, front slant specimen and punch shape (D-FS-P) amendment displays a large increase on the ES value of up to 51% and also about 9% improvement on the IF as compared to the conventional ECAP condition; however, an increase of 6% is anticipated on the RF.

The ES contours for all eight ECAP process conditions are shown in Figure 7. As can be seen, the combination of die geometry, front slant sample and punch shape amendment (Figure 5(h)) cannot be a good choice because of the material flow. So, by considering the difficulties including manufacture of improved die geometry and higher magnitude of extrusion force, die geometry alteration is not recommended. Taking all result values into consideration between P-FS and P-BS, which are favored modifications, P-BS is the most efficient configuration among the eight above-mentioned conditions. Figure 8 represents the general observation of deformed billet after 1-pass ECAP process for the selected amendment (punch shape and back slant sample) obtained with the experimental and numerical procedures.

caption.p: Effective strain contour of ECAPed specimens for the eight various modifications: (a) C, (b) P, (c) FS, (d) BS, (e) P-FS, (f) P-BS, (g) D-FS (h) D-FS-P.
3D view of ECAPed materials using P-BS modification obtained with the experimental and numerical works.

sec.p: By considering the Hall–Petch relationship, the grain size is proportional to the inverse square of the material’s strength. Hence, it can be anticipated that ECAP process of Al6082 leads to reduction at the grain size and hence improvement at the strength value. Optical microscopy (OM) observation and tensile test measurement before and after 1-pass ECAP process using P-BS configuration indicate that there are about 75% reduction at the grain size and also 70% and 21% enhancements at the yield strength (YS) and ultimate tensile strength (UTS), respectively, as shown in Figure 9.

caption.p: Optical microscopy observation and tensile behavior of Al6082 before and after 1-pass ECAP process with P-BS configuration.

sec.title: Effect of die channel and sample slant angles
sec.p: In this section, the angular parameters including die channel and sample slant angles are examined. Figure 10 displays the location of sample slant angle (η) and the die channel angle (Φ) for the P-BS condition. To investigate strain behavior and extrusion force for the modification in the ECAP process, various combinations of the angles η = (30°, 45° and 60°) and Φ = (75°, 90° and 105°) are selected, and the ES magnitude, IF and pressing force are obtained and compared.

caption.p: Observation of angular parameters including sample slant angle (η) and die channel angle (Φ) in the P-BS configuration.

sec.p: From Figure 11, it is obvious that decreasing the die channel angle to 75° from 105° results in 150%, 109% and 71% increase on the ES, IF and RF values, respectively, irrespective of the sample slant angles. On the contrary, there are about 6%, 8% and 5% increase on the ES, IF and required load magnitudes using sample slant angle of 60° instead of 30°, respectively, with constant die channel angle. By comparing the two angular parameters, it is clear that the effect of die channel angle is more considerable than the sample slant angle. As known, what is demanded for the optimum ECAPed materials are as follows: (1) higher magnitude of ES, (2) better strain distribution uniformity (lower IF value) and (3) lower magnitude of required pressing force. As can be seen in Figure 11, there is no ECAP 1process configuration that can satisfy all the three above-mentioned conditions simultaneously. Depending on which design parameters are most important, appropriate ECAP condition can be obtained. One possible condition in Figure 11 is the case that is referred as P-BS (Φ = 75° and η = 30°), showing almost the same RF magnitude with the conventional ECAP situation. It gives about 13% and 35% enhancements for the ES and IF, respectively, as compared to the C condition.

caption.p: Magnitudes of effective strain (ES), inhomogeneity factor (IF) and required extrusion force (RF) for nine various die channel and sample slant angles in the P-BS configuration and C situation.

sec.p: Figure 12 displays strain contour for different die channel and billet slant angles for the P-BS condition, indicating quantitatively where the specimen has the high, medium or low imposed ES.

caption.p: Strain contour of ECAPed specimens in the P-BS configuration for the various die channel and sample slant angles, respectively.

sec.p: Figure 13 shows the required pressing force versus punch displacement for these nine P-BS conditions and also for the C situation. Apparently, curves with the same Φ value can be categorized and distinguished based on their required pressing load. It is clear that for the same magnitude of die channel angle, the maximum pressing force is accomplished faster for the conditions with larger η value than the cases with smaller η value. Also, the larger sample slant angles require slightly greater extrusion loads as compared to the smaller ones for the same Φ value. By continuing the process for each Φ categories, extrusion load curves for the three above-mentioned η angles converge at the midway of the pressing operation. The required punch load is increased with reducing die channel angle because high ES magnitude is imposed to the sample at the lower die channel angle. It can be summarized that the die channel angle has more influence on the required punch force irrespective of the sample slant angle. In addition, the required force magnitude reaches a maximum limit more quickly for the high value of sample slant angle irrespective of the die channel angle.

caption.p: Required pressing force versus punch displacement graphs for ECAPed specimens for the conventional and nine different P-BS configurations.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Improvement of strain homogeneity of deformed materials is one of the important factor for development of various SPD methods, especially ECAP process. In this study, a new specimen and punch modification has been proposed to reduce the head and tail zone effects of ECAPed billet. Prominent conclusions can be drawn as follows.

list-item.p: Eight modifications consisting of punch shape, sample preform and die geometry combinations have been analyzed. Based on the results, modification of punch shape and back slant sample “P-BS” gave better strain distribution uniformity and lower required pressing force. In addition, the P-BS configuration as compared to the conventional ECAP process resulted in 18.7% reduction in the IF and 10% decrease in the required extrusion load.
About 75% reduction at the grain size and also approximately 70% and 21% enhancements at the YS and UTS magnitudes have been achieved by ECAP process after 1 pass on the P-BS configuration.

Furthermore, investigation of various die channel angles and sample slant angles shows that P-BS with the Φ = 75° and η = 30° gave 13% increase in the ES value within the deformed sample and 35% increase in the strain dispersal homogeneity (IF value) for the same extrusion load in comparison with the conventional ECAP process.
